natural problem: Of the four points $(2,2)$, $(9,11)$, $(5,7)$, and $(11,17)$, three lie on the same line. Which point is not on the line?
natural solution: Consider points $P$, $Q$, and $R$. If the slope between point $P$ and point $Q$ is the same as the slope between point $Q$ and point $R$, $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are collinear.
So we must find the slopes between every pair of possible points.

We make a chart of all possible pairs of points and calculate the slope: \begin{tabular}{c|c} Points& Slope \\ \hline \vspace{0.05in} A,B&$\frac{11-2}{9-2}=\frac{9}{7}$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $A,C$&$\frac{7-2}{5-2}=\frac{5}{3}$\\ \vspace{0.05in}
\end{tabular}As we can see, the slopes between $A$ and $C$, $A$ and $D$, and $C$ and $D$ are the same, so $A$, $C$, and $D$ lie on a line, Thus $B$, or the point $\boxed{(9,11)}$, is not on the line.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "A = (2, 2)"
and h1 : "B = (9, 11)"
and h2 : "C = (5, 7)"
and h3 : "D = (11, 17)"
and h4 : "\<exists> a b. a * fst C + b = snd C \<and> a * fst A + b = snd A \<and> a * fst D + b = snd D"
shows  "B \<noteq> (a * fst B + b)" for a b
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the four points $(2,2)$, $(9,11)$, $(5,7)$, and $(11,17)$, three lie on the same line. Which point is not on the line? The final Answer is (9,11)
 ### Proof
 Consider points $P$, $Q$, and $R$. If the slope between point $P$ and point $Q$ is the same as the slope between point $Q$ and point $R$, $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are collinear.
 So we must find the slopes between every pair of possible points.
 Let us name the points: $A=(2,2)$, $B=(9,11)$, $C=(5,7)$, and $D=(11,17)$.
 We make a chart of all possible pairs of points and calculate the slope: \begin{tabular}{c|c} Points& Slope \\ \hline \vspace{0.05in} A,B&$\frac{11-2}{9-2}=\frac{9}{7}$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $A,C$&$\frac{7-2}{5-2}=\frac{5}{3}$\\ \vspace{0.05in}
 $A,D$&$\frac{17-2}{11-2}=\frac{15}{9}=\frac{5}{3}$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $B,C$&$\frac{7-11}{5-9}=\frac{-4}{-4}=1$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $B,D$&$\frac{17-11}{11-9}=\frac{6}{2}=3$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $C,D$&$\frac{17-7}{11-5}=\frac{10}{6}=\frac{5}{3}$
 \end{tabular}As we can see, the slopes between $A$ and $C$, $A$ and $D$, and $C$ and $D$ are the same, so $A$, $C$, and $D$ lie on a line, Thus $B$, or the point $\boxed{(9,11)}$, is not on the line.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "A = (2, 2)"
and h1 : "B = (9, 11)"
and h2 : "C = (5, 7)"
and h3 : "D = (11, 17)"
and h4 : "\<exists> a b. a * fst C + b = snd C \<and> a * fst A + b = snd A \<and> a * fst D + b = snd D"
shows  "B \<noteq> (a * fst B + b)" for a b
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given points A (2, 2), B (9, 11), C (5, 7), and D (11, 17), find the values of a and b such that a line can be determined by the equation y = ax + b, which passes through points A, C, and D. Show that point B does not lie on this line.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "A = (2, 2)"
and h1 : "B = (9, 11)"
and h2 : "C = (5, 7)"
and h3 : "D = (11, 17)"
and h4 : "collinear A C D"
shows  "\<not> collinear A B C"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the four points $(2,2)$, $(9,11)$, $(5,7)$, and $(11,17)$, three lie on the same line. Which point is not on the line? The final Answer is (9,11)
 ### Proof
 Consider points $P$, $Q$, and $R$. If the slope between point $P$ and point $Q$ is the same as the slope between point $Q$ and point $R$, $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are collinear.
 So we must find the slopes between every pair of possible points.
 Let us name the points: $A=(2,2)$, $B=(9,11)$, $C=(5,7)$, and $D=(11,17)$.
 We make a chart of all possible pairs of points and calculate the slope: \begin{tabular}{c|c} Points& Slope \\ \hline \vspace{0.05in} A,B&$\frac{11-2}{9-2}=\frac{9}{7}$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $A,C$&$\frac{7-2}{5-2}=\frac{5}{3}$\\ \vspace{0.05in}
 $A,D$&$\frac{17-2}{11-2}=\frac{15}{9}=\frac{5}{3}$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $B,C$&$\frac{7-11}{5-9}=\frac{-4}{-4}=1$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $B,D$&$\frac{17-11}{11-9}=\frac{6}{2}=3$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $C,D$&$\frac{17-7}{11-5}=\frac{10}{6}=\frac{5}{3}$
 \end{tabular}As we can see, the slopes between $A$ and $C$, $A$ and $D$, and $C$ and $D$ are the same, so $A$, $C$, and $D$ lie on a line, Thus $B$, or the point $\boxed{(9,11)}$, is not on the line.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "A = (2, 2)"
and h1 : "B = (9, 11)"
and h2 : "C = (5, 7)"
and h3 : "D = (11, 17)"
and h4 : "collinear A C D"
shows  "\<not> collinear A B C"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given the points A(2, 2), B(9, 11), C(5, 7), and D(11, 17), if A, C, and D are collinear, prove that A, B, and C are not collinear.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "A = (2, 2)"
and h1 : "B = (9, 11)"
and h2 : "C = (5, 7)"
and h3 : "D = (11, 17)"
and h4 : "collinear {A, C, D}"
shows  "\<not> collinear {A, B, C, D}"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the four points $(2,2)$, $(9,11)$, $(5,7)$, and $(11,17)$, three lie on the same line. Which point is not on the line? The final Answer is (9,11)
 ### Proof
 Consider points $P$, $Q$, and $R$. If the slope between point $P$ and point $Q$ is the same as the slope between point $Q$ and point $R$, $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are collinear.
 So we must find the slopes between every pair of possible points.
 Let us name the points: $A=(2,2)$, $B=(9,11)$, $C=(5,7)$, and $D=(11,17)$.
 We make a chart of all possible pairs of points and calculate the slope: \begin{tabular}{c|c} Points& Slope \\ \hline \vspace{0.05in} A,B&$\frac{11-2}{9-2}=\frac{9}{7}$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $A,C$&$\frac{7-2}{5-2}=\frac{5}{3}$\\ \vspace{0.05in}
 $A,D$&$\frac{17-2}{11-2}=\frac{15}{9}=\frac{5}{3}$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $B,C$&$\frac{7-11}{5-9}=\frac{-4}{-4}=1$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $B,D$&$\frac{17-11}{11-9}=\frac{6}{2}=3$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $C,D$&$\frac{17-7}{11-5}=\frac{10}{6}=\frac{5}{3}$
 \end{tabular}As we can see, the slopes between $A$ and $C$, $A$ and $D$, and $C$ and $D$ are the same, so $A$, $C$, and $D$ lie on a line, Thus $B$, or the point $\boxed{(9,11)}$, is not on the line.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "A = (2, 2)"
and h1 : "B = (9, 11)"
and h2 : "C = (5, 7)"
and h3 : "D = (11, 17)"
and h4 : "collinear {A, C, D}"
shows  "\<not> collinear {A, B, C, D}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given that points $A(2, 2)$, $B(9, 11)$, $C(5, 7)$, and $D(11, 17)$ are in the plane, and points $A$, $C$, and $D$ are collinear, show that points $A$, $B$, $C$, and $D$ are not all collinear.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem not_on_line:
fixes A B C D :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "A = (2, 2)"
and h1 : "B = (9, 11)"
and h2 : "C = (5, 7)"
and h3 : "D = (11, 17)"
and h4 : "collinear {A, C, D}"
shows  "\<not> collinear {A, B, C}"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the four points $(2,2)$, $(9,11)$, $(5,7)$, and $(11,17)$, three lie on the same line. Which point is not on the line? The final Answer is (9,11)
 ### Proof
 Consider points $P$, $Q$, and $R$. If the slope between point $P$ and point $Q$ is the same as the slope between point $Q$ and point $R$, $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are collinear.
 So we must find the slopes between every pair of possible points.
 Let us name the points: $A=(2,2)$, $B=(9,11)$, $C=(5,7)$, and $D=(11,17)$.
 We make a chart of all possible pairs of points and calculate the slope: \begin{tabular}{c|c} Points& Slope \\ \hline \vspace{0.05in} A,B&$\frac{11-2}{9-2}=\frac{9}{7}$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $A,C$&$\frac{7-2}{5-2}=\frac{5}{3}$\\ \vspace{0.05in}
 $A,D$&$\frac{17-2}{11-2}=\frac{15}{9}=\frac{5}{3}$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $B,C$&$\frac{7-11}{5-9}=\frac{-4}{-4}=1$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $B,D$&$\frac{17-11}{11-9}=\frac{6}{2}=3$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $C,D$&$\frac{17-7}{11-5}=\frac{10}{6}=\frac{5}{3}$
 \end{tabular}As we can see, the slopes between $A$ and $C$, $A$ and $D$, and $C$ and $D$ are the same, so $A$, $C$, and $D$ lie on a line, Thus $B$, or the point $\boxed{(9,11)}$, is not on the line.
 *)

theorem not_on_line:
fixes A B C D :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "A = (2, 2)"
and h1 : "B = (9, 11)"
and h2 : "C = (5, 7)"
and h3 : "D = (11, 17)"
and h4 : "collinear {A, C, D}"
shows  "\<not> collinear {A, B, C}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given points A(2, 2), B(9, 11), C(5, 7), and D(11, 17), it is known that A, C, and D are collinear. Prove that A, B, and C are not collinear.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem not_on_line:
fixes A B C D :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "A = (2, 2)"
and h1 : "B = (9, 11)"
and h2 : "C = (5, 7)"
and h3 : "D = (11, 17)"
and h4 : "collinear {A, C, D}"
shows  "B \<notin> collinear {A, C, D}"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the four points $(2,2)$, $(9,11)$, $(5,7)$, and $(11,17)$, three lie on the same line. Which point is not on the line? The final Answer is (9,11)
 ### Proof
 Consider points $P$, $Q$, and $R$. If the slope between point $P$ and point $Q$ is the same as the slope between point $Q$ and point $R$, $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are collinear.
 So we must find the slopes between every pair of possible points.
 Let us name the points: $A=(2,2)$, $B=(9,11)$, $C=(5,7)$, and $D=(11,17)$.
 We make a chart of all possible pairs of points and calculate the slope: \begin{tabular}{c|c} Points& Slope \\ \hline \vspace{0.05in} A,B&$\frac{11-2}{9-2}=\frac{9}{7}$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $A,C$&$\frac{7-2}{5-2}=\frac{5}{3}$\\ \vspace{0.05in}
 $A,D$&$\frac{17-2}{11-2}=\frac{15}{9}=\frac{5}{3}$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $B,C$&$\frac{7-11}{5-9}=\frac{-4}{-4}=1$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $B,D$&$\frac{17-11}{11-9}=\frac{6}{2}=3$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $C,D$&$\frac{17-7}{11-5}=\frac{10}{6}=\frac{5}{3}$
 \end{tabular}As we can see, the slopes between $A$ and $C$, $A$ and $D$, and $C$ and $D$ are the same, so $A$, $C$, and $D$ lie on a line, Thus $B$, or the point $\boxed{(9,11)}$, is not on the line.
 *)

theorem not_on_line:
fixes A B C D :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "A = (2, 2)"
and h1 : "B = (9, 11)"
and h2 : "C = (5, 7)"
and h3 : "D = (11, 17)"
and h4 : "collinear {A, C, D}"
shows  "B \<notin> collinear {A, C, D}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given four points A(2, 2), B(9, 11), C(5, 7), and D(11, 17), it is known that points A, C, and D are collinear. Prove that point B is not collinear with points A, C, and D.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p1 p2 p3 p4 :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "p1 = (2, 2)"
and h1 : "p2 = (9, 11)"
and h2 : "p3 = (5, 7)"
and h3 : "p4 = (11, 17)"
and h4 : "\<exists> k. p1 = k *\<^sub>R p3 + (1 - k) *\<^sub>R p4"
and h5 : "\<exists> k. p2 \<noteq> k *\<^sub>R p3 + (1 - k) *\<^sub>R p4"
shows  "p2 = (9, 11)"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the four points $(2,2)$, $(9,11)$, $(5,7)$, and $(11,17)$, three lie on the same line. Which point is not on the line? The final Answer is (9,11)
 ### Proof
 Consider points $P$, $Q$, and $R$. If the slope between point $P$ and point $Q$ is the same as the slope between point $Q$ and point $R$, $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are collinear.
 So we must find the slopes between every pair of possible points.
 Let us name the points: $A=(2,2)$, $B=(9,11)$, $C=(5,7)$, and $D=(11,17)$.
 We make a chart of all possible pairs of points and calculate the slope: \begin{tabular}{c|c} Points& Slope \\ \hline \vspace{0.05in} A,B&$\frac{11-2}{9-2}=\frac{9}{7}$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $A,C$&$\frac{7-2}{5-2}=\frac{5}{3}$\\ \vspace{0.05in}
 $A,D$&$\frac{17-2}{11-2}=\frac{15}{9}=\frac{5}{3}$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $B,C$&$\frac{7-11}{5-9}=\frac{-4}{-4}=1$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $B,D$&$\frac{17-11}{11-9}=\frac{6}{2}=3$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $C,D$&$\frac{17-7}{11-5}=\frac{10}{6}=\frac{5}{3}$
 \end{tabular}As we can see, the slopes between $A$ and $C$, $A$ and $D$, and $C$ and $D$ are the same, so $A$, $C$, and $D$ lie on a line, Thus $B$, or the point $\boxed{(9,11)}$, is not on the line.
 *)

theorem
fixes p1 p2 p3 p4 :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "p1 = (2, 2)"
and h1 : "p2 = (9, 11)"
and h2 : "p3 = (5, 7)"
and h3 : "p4 = (11, 17)"
and h4 : "\<exists> k. p1 = k *\<^sub>R p3 + (1 - k) *\<^sub>R p4"
and h5 : "\<exists> k. p2 \<noteq> k *\<^sub>R p3 + (1 - k) *\<^sub>R p4"
shows  "p2 = (9, 11)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given four points $p_1 = (2, 2), p_2 = (9, 11), p_3 = (5, 7),$ and $p_4 = (11, 17)$. If there exists a scalar $k$ such that $p_1 = k \cdot p_3 + (1-k) \cdot p_4$, and there is no scalar $k$ for which $p_2 = k \cdot p_3 + (1-k) \cdot p_4$, show that $p_2 = (9, 11)$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "A = (2, 2)"
and h1 : "B = (9, 11)"
and h2 : "C = (5, 7)"
and h3 : "D = (11, 17)"
and h4 : "collinear {A, C, D}"
shows  "\<not>collinear {A, B, C, D}"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the four points $(2,2)$, $(9,11)$, $(5,7)$, and $(11,17)$, three lie on the same line. Which point is not on the line? The final Answer is (9,11)
 ### Proof
 Consider points $P$, $Q$, and $R$. If the slope between point $P$ and point $Q$ is the same as the slope between point $Q$ and point $R$, $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are collinear.
 So we must find the slopes between every pair of possible points.
 Let us name the points: $A=(2,2)$, $B=(9,11)$, $C=(5,7)$, and $D=(11,17)$.
 We make a chart of all possible pairs of points and calculate the slope: \begin{tabular}{c|c} Points& Slope \\ \hline \vspace{0.05in} A,B&$\frac{11-2}{9-2}=\frac{9}{7}$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $A,C$&$\frac{7-2}{5-2}=\frac{5}{3}$\\ \vspace{0.05in}
 $A,D$&$\frac{17-2}{11-2}=\frac{15}{9}=\frac{5}{3}$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $B,C$&$\frac{7-11}{5-9}=\frac{-4}{-4}=1$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $B,D$&$\frac{17-11}{11-9}=\frac{6}{2}=3$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $C,D$&$\frac{17-7}{11-5}=\frac{10}{6}=\frac{5}{3}$
 \end{tabular}As we can see, the slopes between $A$ and $C$, $A$ and $D$, and $C$ and $D$ are the same, so $A$, $C$, and $D$ lie on a line, Thus $B$, or the point $\boxed{(9,11)}$, is not on the line.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "A = (2, 2)"
and h1 : "B = (9, 11)"
and h2 : "C = (5, 7)"
and h3 : "D = (11, 17)"
and h4 : "collinear {A, C, D}"
shows  "\<not>collinear {A, B, C, D}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given four points A(2, 2), B(9, 11), C(5, 7), and D(11, 17), and knowing that points A, C, and D are collinear, determine if all four points A, B, C, and D are collinear. The final answer is that they are not collinear.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B C D :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "A = (2, 2)"
and h1 : "B = (9, 11)"
and h2 : "C = (5, 7)"
and h3 : "D = (11, 17)"
and h4 : "collinear {A, C, D}"
shows  "\<not> collinear {A, B, C, D}"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the four points $(2,2)$, $(9,11)$, $(5,7)$, and $(11,17)$, three lie on the same line. Which point is not on the line? The final Answer is (9,11)
 ### Proof
 Consider points $P$, $Q$, and $R$. If the slope between point $P$ and point $Q$ is the same as the slope between point $Q$ and point $R$, $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are collinear.
 So we must find the slopes between every pair of possible points.
 Let us name the points: $A=(2,2)$, $B=(9,11)$, $C=(5,7)$, and $D=(11,17)$.
 We make a chart of all possible pairs of points and calculate the slope: \begin{tabular}{c|c} Points& Slope \\ \hline \vspace{0.05in} A,B&$\frac{11-2}{9-2}=\frac{9}{7}$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $A,C$&$\frac{7-2}{5-2}=\frac{5}{3}$\\ \vspace{0.05in}
 $A,D$&$\frac{17-2}{11-2}=\frac{15}{9}=\frac{5}{3}$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $B,C$&$\frac{7-11}{5-9}=\frac{-4}{-4}=1$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $B,D$&$\frac{17-11}{11-9}=\frac{6}{2}=3$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $C,D$&$\frac{17-7}{11-5}=\frac{10}{6}=\frac{5}{3}$
 \end{tabular}As we can see, the slopes between $A$ and $C$, $A$ and $D$, and $C$ and $D$ are the same, so $A$, $C$, and $D$ lie on a line, Thus $B$, or the point $\boxed{(9,11)}$, is not on the line.
 *)

theorem
fixes A B C D :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "A = (2, 2)"
and h1 : "B = (9, 11)"
and h2 : "C = (5, 7)"
and h3 : "D = (11, 17)"
and h4 : "collinear {A, C, D}"
shows  "\<not> collinear {A, B, C, D}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given four points A(2, 2), B(9, 11), C(5, 7), and D(11, 17), it is known that points A, C, and D are collinear. Determine if all four points are collinear. The final answer is no.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes point_on_line :: "(real * real) => bool"
assumes h0 : "point_on_line (2, 2)"
and h1 : "point_on_line (5, 7)"
and h2 : "point_on_line (11, 17)"
shows  "\<not> point_on_line (9, 11)"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the four points $(2,2)$, $(9,11)$, $(5,7)$, and $(11,17)$, three lie on the same line. Which point is not on the line? The final Answer is (9,11)
 ### Proof
 Consider points $P$, $Q$, and $R$. If the slope between point $P$ and point $Q$ is the same as the slope between point $Q$ and point $R$, $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are collinear.
 So we must find the slopes between every pair of possible points.
 Let us name the points: $A=(2,2)$, $B=(9,11)$, $C=(5,7)$, and $D=(11,17)$.
 We make a chart of all possible pairs of points and calculate the slope: \begin{tabular}{c|c} Points& Slope \\ \hline \vspace{0.05in} A,B&$\frac{11-2}{9-2}=\frac{9}{7}$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $A,C$&$\frac{7-2}{5-2}=\frac{5}{3}$\\ \vspace{0.05in}
 $A,D$&$\frac{17-2}{11-2}=\frac{15}{9}=\frac{5}{3}$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $B,C$&$\frac{7-11}{5-9}=\frac{-4}{-4}=1$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $B,D$&$\frac{17-11}{11-9}=\frac{6}{2}=3$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $C,D$&$\frac{17-7}{11-5}=\frac{10}{6}=\frac{5}{3}$
 \end{tabular}As we can see, the slopes between $A$ and $C$, $A$ and $D$, and $C$ and $D$ are the same, so $A$, $C$, and $D$ lie on a line, Thus $B$, or the point $\boxed{(9,11)}$, is not on the line.
 *)

theorem
fixes point_on_line :: "(real * real) => bool"
assumes h0 : "point_on_line (2, 2)"
and h1 : "point_on_line (5, 7)"
and h2 : "point_on_line (11, 17)"
shows  "\<not> point_on_line (9, 11)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Three points, (2, 2), (5, 7), and (11, 17), lie on a straight line. Show that the point (9, 11) does not lie on this line.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem not_on_line:
fixes A B C D :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "A = (2, 2)"
and h1 : "B = (9, 11)"
and h2 : "C = (5, 7)"
and h3 : "D = (11, 17)"
and h4 : "\<forall> P Q R. collinear P Q R \<longrightarrow> (B \<noteq> P \<or> B \<noteq> Q \<or> B \<noteq> R)"
shows  "\<not> collinear A B C"
and "\<not> collinear A B D"
and "\<not> collinear B C D"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Of the four points $(2,2)$, $(9,11)$, $(5,7)$, and $(11,17)$, three lie on the same line. Which point is not on the line? The final Answer is (9,11)
 ### Proof
 Consider points $P$, $Q$, and $R$. If the slope between point $P$ and point $Q$ is the same as the slope between point $Q$ and point $R$, $P$, $Q$, and $R$ are collinear.
 So we must find the slopes between every pair of possible points.
 Let us name the points: $A=(2,2)$, $B=(9,11)$, $C=(5,7)$, and $D=(11,17)$.
 We make a chart of all possible pairs of points and calculate the slope: \begin{tabular}{c|c} Points& Slope \\ \hline \vspace{0.05in} A,B&$\frac{11-2}{9-2}=\frac{9}{7}$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $A,C$&$\frac{7-2}{5-2}=\frac{5}{3}$\\ \vspace{0.05in}
 $A,D$&$\frac{17-2}{11-2}=\frac{15}{9}=\frac{5}{3}$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $B,C$&$\frac{7-11}{5-9}=\frac{-4}{-4}=1$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $B,D$&$\frac{17-11}{11-9}=\frac{6}{2}=3$\\ \vspace{0.05in} $C,D$&$\frac{17-7}{11-5}=\frac{10}{6}=\frac{5}{3}$
 \end{tabular}As we can see, the slopes between $A$ and $C$, $A$ and $D$, and $C$ and $D$ are the same, so $A$, $C$, and $D$ lie on a line, Thus $B$, or the point $\boxed{(9,11)}$, is not on the line.
 *)

theorem not_on_line:
fixes A B C D :: "real * real"
assumes h0 : "A = (2, 2)"
and h1 : "B = (9, 11)"
and h2 : "C = (5, 7)"
and h3 : "D = (11, 17)"
and h4 : "\<forall> P Q R. collinear P Q R \<longrightarrow> (B \<noteq> P \<or> B \<noteq> Q \<or> B \<noteq> R)"
shows  "\<not> collinear A B C"
and "\<not> collinear A B D"
and "\<not> collinear B C D"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given four points A(2, 2), B(9, 11), C(5, 7), and D(11, 17), prove that B cannot be collinear with any other two points, i.e., A, B, and C are not collinear; A, B, and D are not collinear; and B, C, and D are not collinear.
